sections.1_story_intuition: Indian Polity covers the structure, functioning, and principles of the Indian Constitution and government. It is a core subject for competitive exams, as questions are frequently asked about the Constitution, fundamental rights, duties, and the working of various government bodies.
2_key_definitions: Constitution: The supreme law of India, laying down the framework for governance.
Preamble: Introduction to the Constitution stating its ideals.
Fundamental Rights: Basic rights guaranteed to all citizens.
Directive Principles: Guidelines for the government to ensure social and economic welfare.
Parliament: The supreme legislative body of India.
President: The ceremonial head of state.
Prime Minister: The head of government.
Supreme Court: The highest judicial authority.
Federalism: Division of powers between central and state governments.
Amendment: A formal change to the Constitution.
3_key_facts_data_points: The Constitution of India was adopted on 26th November 1949 and came into effect on 26th January 1950.
It is the longest written constitution in the world.
Original Constitution had 395 Articles, 22 Parts, and 8 Schedules.
Currently, there are 25 Parts, 12 Schedules, and over 470 Articles.
The Preamble declares India as a Sovereign, Socialist, Secular, Democratic Republic.
Fundamental Rights are covered from Article 12 to 35.
Directive Principles are from Article 36 to 51.
The President is elected for a 5-year term.
The Parliament consists of Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha.
The Prime Minister is the leader of the majority party in Lok Sabha.
Supreme Court is the apex court, established in 1950.
India follows a federal system with a unitary bias.
First Constitutional Amendment was in 1951.
Emergency provisions are in Articles 352-360.
The 42nd Amendment is called the 'Mini Constitution'.
Right to Education was made a Fundamental Right by the 86th Amendment.
Finance Commission is constituted every 5 years.
Election Commission conducts free and fair elections.
Governor is the head of a state.
Chief Minister is the head of a state government.
4_micro_notes: India's Constitution is the world's longest.
Lok Sabha: Lower House, Rajya Sabha: Upper House.
Supreme Court has original, appellate, and advisory jurisdiction.
Emergency can be declared by President.
5_exam_capsules: When was the Constitution adopted? 26th November 1949.
When did it come into effect? 26th January 1950.
Which Article deals with Right to Equality? Article 14.
Which Article deals with Right to Education? Article 21A.
Who is the head of state? President.
Who is the head of government? Prime Minister.
Which is the Upper House? Rajya Sabha.
Which is the Lower House? Lok Sabha.
What is the 42nd Amendment known as? Mini Constitution.
Who appoints the Prime Minister? President.
Which body conducts elections? Election Commission.
What is the tenure of the President? 5 years.
Which Article deals with Emergency? Article 352.
How many Schedules are there now? 12.
What is the minimum age for Lok Sabha? 25 years.
Who is the head of a state? Governor.
Who is the head of a state government? Chief Minister.
7_traps_confusing_points: Confusing Lok Sabha (Lower House) with Rajya Sabha (Upper House).
Mixing up Fundamental Rights and Directive Principles.
Assuming President is the real executive (it's the Prime Minister).
Confusing number of Articles and Schedules.
Mixing up tenure of President and Prime Minister.
Assuming all amendments need state ratification.
Confusing original and appellate jurisdiction of Supreme Court.
Mixing up roles of Governor and Chief Minister.
Assuming all states have Legislative Councils.

8_case_study_context.title: The 42nd Amendment (1976)
8_case_study_context.explanation: The 42nd Amendment, known as the 'Mini Constitution', brought major changes to the Indian Constitution, including the addition of 'Secular' and 'Integrity' to the Preamble, and strengthening the Directive Principles. It is considered the most comprehensive amendment in Indian constitutional history.
